name: Sample Videos
subtitle: Select videos from the Course Library

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike cover installing Windows Server 2012R2 with a GUI interface. Once installed, they demonstrate how to configure the server using server manager and get the server ready for a production environment.
episodes.title: Installing Server with GUI
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.007 --> 00:00:10.561
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.561 --> 00:00:15.000
All right greetings everyone, welcome
to another great episode of ITPro TV.

3
00:00:15.000 --> 00:00:16.680
I'm your host Daniel Arin,
and here with me,

4
00:00:16.680 --> 00:00:19.130
a man who knows a lot
about Windows Server.

5
00:00:19.130 --> 00:00:20.150
That man is Mike Rodrick.

6
00:00:20.150 --> 00:00:21.330
How's it going to day Mike?

7
00:00:21.330 --> 00:00:22.350
>> It's going great Daniel.

8
00:00:22.350 --> 00:00:23.840
I'm excited to be here.

9
00:00:23.840 --> 00:00:28.375
In this episode, we're gonna look at
installing Windows Server 2012 R2.

10
00:00:28.375 --> 00:00:30.790
Now when we install a server there's
a couple of different ways we

11
00:00:30.790 --> 00:00:31.430
could install it.

12
00:00:31.430 --> 00:00:34.780
In this first episode we're
gonna look at installing it,

13
00:00:34.780 --> 00:00:36.390
what I would like to call normally.

14
00:00:36.390 --> 00:00:38.140
>> Right, just the de facto.

15
00:00:38.140 --> 00:00:39.010
>> Yeah, right?

16
00:00:39.010 --> 00:00:43.050
When you install a server, or you install
any operating system you expect to

17
00:00:43.050 --> 00:00:46.260
finish it, reboot that machine and
you come up and you login and

18
00:00:46.260 --> 00:00:49.240
you've got a desktop and
all of that good stuff, right and

19
00:00:49.240 --> 00:00:52.550
we can interact with our keyboard and
our mouse and that kind of thing.

20
00:00:52.550 --> 00:00:55.370
And we can definitely do that with server,
it's not the only option.

21
00:00:55.370 --> 00:00:59.060
We're going to cover some of the other
options in some later episodes.

22
00:00:59.060 --> 00:01:02.110
In this one, we're going to install
it again, what I call normally.

23
00:01:02.110 --> 00:01:06.580
What Microsoft's going to call
is a full or standard install.

24
00:01:06.580 --> 00:01:09.150
That means we're going to install server,
and when we're done,

25
00:01:09.150 --> 00:01:10.660
we're going to have a desktop.

26
00:01:10.660 --> 00:01:11.400
We're going to have a GUI.

27
00:01:11.400 --> 00:01:15.470
We're going to have all those
administrative tools that we need so

28
00:01:15.470 --> 00:01:16.790
to work with our server.

29
00:01:16.790 --> 00:01:21.400
And I think that's what most people
are probably used to or accustomed to.

30
00:01:21.400 --> 00:01:25.620
But before we install it, we need to
talk about what our requirements are.

31
00:01:25.620 --> 00:01:28.150
We need to know what it
is that I need to have

32
00:01:28.150 --> 00:01:32.400
to make sure that I can successfully
install server 2012 R2.

33
00:01:32.400 --> 00:01:33.400
>> I've got a 386 Mike.

34
00:01:33.400 --> 00:01:36.360
That's plenty of horsepower, right?

35
00:01:36.360 --> 00:01:38.021
>> Sure, should be perfect, right.

36
00:01:38.021 --> 00:01:40.705
[LAUGH] You could use that if
you don't want it to work.

37
00:01:40.705 --> 00:01:42.640
[LAUGH]
>> He was hoping.

38
00:01:42.640 --> 00:01:43.730
>> Yeah, you know.

39
00:01:43.730 --> 00:01:47.230
You'd be surprised, you're close actually.

40
00:01:47.230 --> 00:01:48.280
It doesn't take a lot.

41
00:01:48.280 --> 00:01:50.200
But it is going to take
a little bit more than a 386.

42
00:01:50.200 --> 00:01:54.230
For the processor, you're going to need

43
00:01:54.230 --> 00:01:59.340
at least a 1.4 gigahertz 64 bit processor.

44
00:01:59.340 --> 00:02:04.270
For memory, now get this one Daniel,
512 megabytes of RAM.

45
00:02:04.270 --> 00:02:05.380
>> Wow.
That's not a lot.

46
00:02:05.380 --> 00:02:06.040
>> It's not much.

47
00:02:06.040 --> 00:02:07.820
>> That's, that's pretty cheap nowadays.

48
00:02:07.820 --> 00:02:08.530
>> It really is.

49
00:02:08.530 --> 00:02:11.230
I mean you can't buy a box
with less than that.

50
00:02:11.230 --> 00:02:15.500
And for your disc space, you're going to
need 32 gigabytes of free disk space.

51
00:02:15.500 --> 00:02:16.480
>> Also not a lot.

52
00:02:16.480 --> 00:02:17.352
>> Easy breezy right.

53
00:02:17.352 --> 00:02:18.336
>> [CROSSTALK] I mean it
will work out pretty easily.

54
00:02:18.336 --> 00:02:19.335
>> Yeah absolutely.

55
00:02:19.335 --> 00:02:21.580
Here's the catch though.

56
00:02:21.580 --> 00:02:25.100
Those are what we call
the minimum system requirements.

57
00:02:25.100 --> 00:02:30.058
What that means is you can install Server
2012 R2 with a 1.4 gigahertz processor.

58
00:02:30.058 --> 00:02:36.300
A 32 gigabyte drive or freespace,
32 gigabytes and 512 megabytes of RAM.

59
00:02:36.300 --> 00:02:40.100
Now the question is, are you gonna be
happy with the performance of that server

60
00:02:40.100 --> 00:02:41.160
when you're done installing it?

61
00:02:41.160 --> 00:02:41.752
What do you think, Daniel?

62
00:02:41.752 --> 00:02:43.713
>> It'll probably run like a sick dog.

63
00:02:43.713 --> 00:02:46.465
[LAUGH] Not very well or far.

64
00:02:46.465 --> 00:02:47.672
>> Exactly.

65
00:02:47.672 --> 00:02:51.515
It's gonna just chug along and the other
thing you've got to keep in mind,

66
00:02:51.515 --> 00:02:54.370
that's just for
the operating system itself.

67
00:02:54.370 --> 00:02:59.060
So if I wanna add roles, and I wanna
add DNS or DHCP or Active Directory and

68
00:02:59.060 --> 00:03:02.000
things like that, I've gotta go look
at what the requirements are for

69
00:03:02.000 --> 00:03:05.730
those roles cuz they're gonna require,
like DNS is memory intensive.

70
00:03:05.730 --> 00:03:07.670
It has to load of up all of those zones.

71
00:03:07.670 --> 00:03:10.260
So depending on what
roles we're installing

72
00:03:10.260 --> 00:03:13.160
I've gotta add to those requirements.

73
00:03:13.160 --> 00:03:13.770
Right?

74
00:03:13.770 --> 00:03:18.940
So yes, you could install Server 2012
R2 with a 1.4 gigahertz processor,

75
00:03:18.940 --> 00:03:22.570
512 megs of RAM,
32 gigabytes of free disk space.

76
00:03:22.570 --> 00:03:24.440
But in the end,
you're never gonna do that.

77
00:03:24.440 --> 00:03:25.000
Right?
Because you're

78
00:03:25.000 --> 00:03:28.190
not just going to install a server and
let it sit there and run.

79
00:03:28.190 --> 00:03:30.400
Right.
But for the exam you gotta know what those

80
00:03:30.400 --> 00:03:33.010
minimum requirements are so
that's why we're informing you.

81
00:03:33.010 --> 00:03:36.090
But in the real world, Danny,
you're not gonna install a server,

82
00:03:36.090 --> 00:03:37.650
processor wise, the biggest,

83
00:03:37.650 --> 00:03:41.200
baddest processor you got, as many
processors as you can put in there, right?

84
00:03:41.200 --> 00:03:42.990
It's gonna make it run better.

85
00:03:42.990 --> 00:03:47.410
Memory wise, I don't think I've ever run
a server with less than two gigs of RAM.

86
00:03:47.410 --> 00:03:51.760
In a virtualized environment, and
looking at some of our install options,

87
00:03:51.760 --> 00:03:55.475
maybe a little bit less, but
I would say two gigs minimum, real world.

88
00:03:55.475 --> 00:03:56.908
[SOUND]
>> It's a must have.

89
00:03:56.908 --> 00:04:01.000
I've run plenty of virtual servers,
and physical servers.

90
00:04:01.000 --> 00:04:04.350
Two gigs is, in my opinion,
the bare minimum.

91
00:04:04.350 --> 00:04:06.670
Otherwise, like we said,
it's gonna run like a sick dog.

92
00:04:06.670 --> 00:04:11.420
It's just not gonna give you even just
a standard experience when you think,

93
00:04:11.420 --> 00:04:12.580
the mouse moves.

94
00:04:12.580 --> 00:04:14.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> And you double click on something and

95
00:04:14.740 --> 00:04:17.230
it opens up in some sort of timely manner.

96
00:04:17.230 --> 00:04:19.120
Or you're not running
off to the bathroom and

97
00:04:19.120 --> 00:04:20.500
getting a cup of coffee,
and doing all that.

98
00:04:20.500 --> 00:04:22.790
You come back, you're still waiting for
the hourglass to spin.

99
00:04:22.790 --> 00:04:24.430
Now, we want some performance.

100
00:04:24.430 --> 00:04:27.380
Servers usually require
a little bit performance.

101
00:04:27.380 --> 00:04:32.550
Like Mike said, you can put this
on a minimal amount of hardware,

102
00:04:32.550 --> 00:04:33.820
and they give you that.

103
00:04:33.820 --> 00:04:35.530
And that's for like worst case scenario.

104
00:04:35.530 --> 00:04:39.540
This is all you have laying around,
old stuff sitting in a closet somewhere.

105
00:04:39.540 --> 00:04:42.740
But if you have the means,
we're going to go ahead and tell you.

106
00:04:42.740 --> 00:04:44.700
Go ahead and
grab some more hard drive space,

107
00:04:44.700 --> 00:04:47.640
go ahead and grab some more CPU power,
a little more RAM.

108
00:04:47.640 --> 00:04:50.610
You'll probably have an easier time
making this thing do what it is.

109
00:04:50.610 --> 00:04:52.225
You'd like it to do right Mike.

110
00:04:52.225 --> 00:04:53.620
>> Exactly, exactly.

111
00:04:53.620 --> 00:04:56.940
So give it as much resources
as you've got available

112
00:04:56.940 --> 00:04:58.570
to make that performance acceptable.

113
00:04:58.570 --> 00:05:01.220
All right so
we've got our minimum requirements down.

114
00:05:01.220 --> 00:05:04.740
The next thing we've got to do is just
go ahead and install Server 2012 R2 and

115
00:05:04.740 --> 00:05:09.820
like I said we can install server
a couple of different ways.

116
00:05:09.820 --> 00:05:12.240
And I'll show you when we
go through our demo here.

117
00:05:12.240 --> 00:05:14.160
So let me go ahead and fire up my machine.

118
00:05:15.840 --> 00:05:20.320
And I've got a virtual machine here and
it's already got the ISO loaded up so

119
00:05:20.320 --> 00:05:23.880
your Server 2012 R2 disc
is in the CD-ROM drive.

120
00:05:25.240 --> 00:05:29.790
And while that's loading up I'm
gonna go run grab a key for

121
00:05:29.790 --> 00:05:32.890
this and I can throw this link
out there for you guys later.

122
00:05:32.890 --> 00:05:36.270
These are some KMS keys
provided by Microsoft.

123
00:05:36.270 --> 00:05:39.330
They're not valid keys,
they won't actually activate,

124
00:05:39.330 --> 00:05:43.070
they'll allow to get through that
install for labs and things like that.

125
00:05:43.070 --> 00:05:47.030
They're designed really for KMS setups
when you're setting up a licensing server

126
00:05:47.030 --> 00:05:50.040
but you need to get the image installed
first before it can reach out and

127
00:05:50.040 --> 00:05:51.630
talk to your licensing server.

128
00:05:51.630 --> 00:05:53.120
That's what those keys are for.

129
00:05:53.120 --> 00:05:55.570
So I'm gonna grab one of those real quick.

130
00:05:55.570 --> 00:05:57.250
And now back over to the virtual machine.

131
00:05:57.250 --> 00:05:59.810
So, again, I've put that disk in and

132
00:05:59.810 --> 00:06:02.540
of course the server
2012 R2 disk is bootable.

133
00:06:02.540 --> 00:06:03.710
So the server is booting up.

134
00:06:03.710 --> 00:06:05.530
There's nothing on the hard drive.

135
00:06:05.530 --> 00:06:09.170
So I didn't have to hit, like,
the any key to boot to the CD Rom.

136
00:06:09.170 --> 00:06:10.070
It's gonna straight to it.

137
00:06:10.070 --> 00:06:13.040
Because it sees that there's
nothing on the hard drive there.

138
00:06:13.040 --> 00:06:16.160
>> I would assume this would
also work with USB drives and

139
00:06:16.160 --> 00:06:19.860
just putting the ISO on that, and
pop that in set it to boot from USB.

140
00:06:19.860 --> 00:06:21.230
You'll probably get the same effect.

141
00:06:21.230 --> 00:06:21.880
>> Exactly.

142
00:06:21.880 --> 00:06:25.210
The only thing you might have to do is
make sure in the BIOS of that machine,

143
00:06:25.210 --> 00:06:27.370
that it's allowed to boot to the USB.

144
00:06:27.370 --> 00:06:29.325
Sometimes you've gotta go in and
turn that feature on.

145
00:06:29.325 --> 00:06:31.180
>> Awesome.
>> All right, so there we go, so

146
00:06:31.180 --> 00:06:33.340
this is the screen that's gonna pop up,
and

147
00:06:33.340 --> 00:06:36.940
installing Server 2012 R2
is extremely easy really.

148
00:06:36.940 --> 00:06:38.770
It's going to walk me through the process.

149
00:06:38.770 --> 00:06:42.443
The first thing it asks me is what
language I want to use, what my time and

150
00:06:42.443 --> 00:06:45.506
currency format's going to be and
what my keyboard or input

151
00:06:45.506 --> 00:06:49.637
method is going to be and there are drop
down lists and you can pick from several.

152
00:06:49.637 --> 00:06:54.430
Well, except for this particular disk,
I think, is only US or EN-US.

153
00:06:54.430 --> 00:06:56.120
So I don't get to see
all the other languages.

154
00:06:56.120 --> 00:06:59.230
Which is great for
me because that's my native language.

155
00:06:59.230 --> 00:07:00.040
That's what I speak, so.

156
00:07:00.040 --> 00:07:01.590
>> You don't like it in Africana?

157
00:07:01.590 --> 00:07:04.010
>> You know,
I don't speak Chinese very well so

158
00:07:04.010 --> 00:07:06.300
I'm not gonna have a very
good time installing it.

159
00:07:06.300 --> 00:07:07.160
>> There is that.

160
00:07:07.160 --> 00:07:09.340
>> [LAUGH] So
I'll go ahead and click Next.

161
00:07:10.380 --> 00:07:12.590
And then, Install Now.

162
00:07:12.590 --> 00:07:14.910
I don't know.
So far, what do you think Daniel?

163
00:07:14.910 --> 00:07:17.180
>> You know what, since Windows 7 really,

164
00:07:17.180 --> 00:07:19.810
I've thought Microsoft has done
a really good job with their installer.

165
00:07:19.810 --> 00:07:21.290
It used to be a little bit more difficult,

166
00:07:21.290 --> 00:07:25.810
especially back if you come from Windows
3.1 and Windows 95 and Windows 98.

167
00:07:25.810 --> 00:07:28.120
You had to use boot discs and
all this other stuff,

168
00:07:28.120 --> 00:07:31.180
to do formatting of disc utilities and
stuff like that.

169
00:07:31.180 --> 00:07:34.350
These graphical interfaces for
installation make our lives

170
00:07:34.350 --> 00:07:38.590
a whole lot easier, and
quickly too, it doesn't take long.

171
00:07:38.590 --> 00:07:41.620
I think I successfully splint
up either a Windows 7 or

172
00:07:41.620 --> 00:07:43.344
Windows 8.1 in under ten minutes.

173
00:07:43.344 --> 00:07:46.550
>> Yeah.
>> Under ten minutes from start to finish.

174
00:07:46.550 --> 00:07:50.410
Blank disk to working the operating
system in under ten minutes.

175
00:07:50.410 --> 00:07:51.911
That's really good, so

176
00:07:51.911 --> 00:07:56.130
I expect some performance somewhere
along those lines with servers.

177
00:07:56.130 --> 00:07:57.250
>> Absolutely, absolutely.

178
00:07:57.250 --> 00:07:59.819
Cuz remember, we're not extracting
all those files out anymore,

179
00:07:59.819 --> 00:08:02.480
decompressing them over the hard drive,
things like that.

180
00:08:02.480 --> 00:08:03.955
We're basically applying an image, right?

181
00:08:03.955 --> 00:08:09.540
There's a WHM file on that disc, on that
DVD, and that's really all you're doing.

182
00:08:09.540 --> 00:08:12.620
So I'm gonna go ahead and paste that key
in there, hopefully that'll paste in.

183
00:08:12.620 --> 00:08:13.510
Very good.

184
00:08:13.510 --> 00:08:15.510
So there's my product key.

185
00:08:15.510 --> 00:08:16.482
I'll click Next.

186
00:08:19.421 --> 00:08:25.030
And then I get to choose which edition
basically, or version I want to install.

187
00:08:25.030 --> 00:08:28.190
Now depending on the disk you have,
you might see different options.

188
00:08:28.190 --> 00:08:32.655
The key that I just put in was for
2012 R2 Standard.

189
00:08:32.655 --> 00:08:36.690
So notice the only thing that
shows up is 2012 R2 Standard.

190
00:08:36.690 --> 00:08:40.300
With the right disk though it
includes all the different editions.

191
00:08:40.300 --> 00:08:44.226
So if I had got the data center key and
put that in there, when I got to this

192
00:08:44.226 --> 00:08:48.437
screen it would have given me the option
to choose Data center if I wanted to.

193
00:08:48.437 --> 00:08:50.120
And then you can see I've got two options.

194
00:08:50.120 --> 00:08:53.870
I've got server core, and
I've got server with a GUI.

195
00:08:53.870 --> 00:08:56.560
Notice that the default
is actually server core.

196
00:08:56.560 --> 00:08:58.910
This is what Microsoft wants us to use.

197
00:08:58.910 --> 00:09:02.720
And I'm going to do another episode where
we cover installing server core, and

198
00:09:02.720 --> 00:09:04.340
seeing how to configure that.

199
00:09:04.340 --> 00:09:07.290
For right now,
we're going to go server with a GUI.

200
00:09:07.290 --> 00:09:08.151
And I'll click Next.

201
00:09:11.657 --> 00:09:14.346
And then of course I'm gonna
have to agree to the EULA or

202
00:09:14.346 --> 00:09:15.929
I'm not gonna get any further.

203
00:09:15.929 --> 00:09:18.959
>> That's one of my favorite
types of things that happen.

204
00:09:18.959 --> 00:09:23.018
I'll get a user that'll call me up and say
oh I've got this thing on my screen and

205
00:09:23.018 --> 00:09:24.360
I don't know what to do.

206
00:09:24.360 --> 00:09:27.580
And there's only one option,
like Mike has right here, do I accept it?

207
00:09:27.580 --> 00:09:29.330
If I don't I can't go any further.

208
00:09:29.330 --> 00:09:32.250
So if you see these types of things,
there's only one option.

209
00:09:32.250 --> 00:09:33.529
That's your option.

210
00:09:33.529 --> 00:09:35.737
[LAUGH]
>> Notice my uncheck at the next

211
00:09:35.737 --> 00:09:36.810
button-
>> Just goes

212
00:09:36.810 --> 00:09:37.760
away
>> Yeah.

213
00:09:37.760 --> 00:09:40.190
So you're pretty much
forced to choose that.

214
00:09:40.190 --> 00:09:40.778
I'll click Next.

215
00:09:40.778 --> 00:09:44.030
And then I have to tell it
where I want to install it.

216
00:09:44.030 --> 00:09:45.201
Now it could be doing an upgrade.

217
00:09:45.201 --> 00:09:48.301
Maybe this computer already has
an operating system on it and

218
00:09:48.301 --> 00:09:50.745
I'm trying to upgrade to server 2012 R2.

219
00:09:50.745 --> 00:09:52.980
Again that will be another
episode we'll deal with that.

220
00:09:52.980 --> 00:09:56.060
For this one I'm just going to use
custom install because I don't have

221
00:09:56.060 --> 00:09:57.160
anything to upgrade.

222
00:09:57.160 --> 00:09:59.320
So I couldn't choose that upgrade option.

223
00:09:59.320 --> 00:10:02.970
And then it's gonna scan and
show me what hard drives I have available.

224
00:10:02.970 --> 00:10:06.011
I see I have one drive that's
60 gigabytes in size, so

225
00:10:06.011 --> 00:10:09.067
that meets my minimum
requirements of 32 gigabytes.

226
00:10:09.067 --> 00:10:12.379
I could go ahead and
create a partition here if I wanted to,

227
00:10:12.379 --> 00:10:14.284
if I had a 500 gigabyte drive.

228
00:10:14.284 --> 00:10:19.510
And I wanted to go ahead and create a 64
gigabyte partition to install the OS in.

229
00:10:19.510 --> 00:10:22.220
And use the other space for

I only pay for five minutes of usage,

The one time that that really doesn't

00:30:46.540 --> 00:30:50.080
Another scenario might be that
you need specialized hardware.

655
00:30:50.080 --> 00:30:53.880
Daniel and I, we used to work together at
an insurance company years and years back.

656
00:30:53.880 --> 00:30:55.250
And at that company,

657
00:30:55.250 --> 00:30:58.190
we had a fax server which,
do you remember the fax server, Dan?

658
00:30:58.190 --> 00:30:59.850
>> Oh, I remember the fax server.

659
00:30:59.850 --> 00:31:01.477
>> It was a ray of sunshine, wasn't it?

660
00:31:01.477 --> 00:31:02.150
>> It completely was.

661
00:31:02.150 --> 00:31:04.348
[LAUGH]
>> The thing about the fax server is

662
00:31:04.348 --> 00:31:08.012
it had this special modem board in
it that had, is it 8 or 16 ports,

663
00:31:08.012 --> 00:31:11.697
something crazy on there, so
that we could receive all these faxes.

664
00:31:11.697 --> 00:31:13.650
Well, I can't virtualize that system.

665
00:31:13.650 --> 00:31:15.970
I need that fax board,
I can't put that in Azure.

666
00:31:15.970 --> 00:31:18.770
I'm gonna have to have a physical server
for that, there's no way around it.

667
00:31:18.770 --> 00:31:23.355
So there are scenarios where Azure doesn't
work, but pricing isn't one of them.

668
00:31:23.355 --> 00:31:27.781
Azure always ends up being cheaper than
your physical server unless you do really

669
00:31:27.781 --> 00:31:32.153
like white box, build your own,
off the shelf, non-name brand type server.

670
00:31:32.153 --> 00:31:34.925
But then you have a higher
mean time between failure, and

671
00:31:34.925 --> 00:31:38.300
you end up losing all that savings
on the support side on the back end.

672
00:31:38.300 --> 00:31:41.825
We've all done it, we've all kind
of worked in that environment, and

673
00:31:41.825 --> 00:31:44.486
it's nice having Microsoft
worry about that for us.

674
00:31:44.486 --> 00:31:48.000
>> Yeah, when you buy a server,
it's not just buying a box.

675
00:31:48.000 --> 00:31:50.740
It's a lot of things
that go along with that.

676
00:31:50.740 --> 00:31:54.670
You gotta pay a guy like me or Don here or
maybe yourself, to make sure it's running,

677
00:31:54.670 --> 00:31:55.670
it's doing everything.

678
00:31:55.670 --> 00:31:58.280
When we go into the cloud,
that all gets pushed off.

679
00:31:58.280 --> 00:32:02.032
We get to be freed up to do more important
things, developing infrastructure,

680
00:32:02.032 --> 00:32:03.320
working support tickets,

681
00:32:03.320 --> 00:32:06.970
things that are much more important
than swapping out hard drives and stuff.

682
00:32:06.970 --> 00:32:07.620
So Don,

683
00:32:07.620 --> 00:32:11.130
is there anything else we need to cover
in this show before we close it down?

684
00:32:11.130 --> 00:32:12.350
>> That's it for the basics.

685
00:32:12.350 --> 00:32:16.140
We're gonna move on to talking about
actually creating the VMs, and

686
00:32:16.140 --> 00:32:19.850
I know I showed some information up here
that I didn't explain in great detail.

687
00:32:19.850 --> 00:32:21.670
We're gonna see that in
the upcoming episodes.

688
00:32:21.670 --> 00:32:23.220
So we got a lot more to go into.

689
00:32:23.220 --> 00:32:25.690
But I just wanted to make sure I started
off with the basics of Azure for

690
00:32:25.690 --> 00:32:28.430
those of you that haven't used it or
aren't familiar with it.

691
00:32:28.430 --> 00:32:30.207
It really is a great system,
you'll enjoy it.

692
00:32:30.207 --> 00:32:31.213
It's pretty easy to use and

693
00:32:31.213 --> 00:32:34.294
definitely something you'll wanna take
advantage of out there in the real world.

694
00:32:34.294 --> 00:32:35.900
>> That's right, excellent stuff, Don.

695
00:32:35.900 --> 00:32:37.090
Thanks for joining us today.

696
00:32:37.090 --> 00:32:39.710
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

697
00:32:39.710 --> 00:32:40.938
I've been your host, Daniel Lowery.

698
00:32:40.938 --> 00:32:41.693
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.title: Computer Forensics in Todays World

WEBVTT

1

And welcome to another

13

14

>> Good, good.
Thank you.

15

Version 9,

16

>> Right.
>> That's what we're going with.

17
00:00:33.580 --> 00:00:34.560
>> Now with more versioning.

18

>> Now with more versioning,
than we have with version 8.

19
00:00:37.050 --> 00:00:38.150
So glad to be back.

20
00:00:38.150 --> 00:00:39.910
Glad to be spending time
with you as always.

21
00:00:39.910 --> 00:00:41.530
We're gonna start talking about CHFI.

22
00:00:41.530 --> 00:00:44.540
Very exciting area of knowledge and
content.

23
00:00:44.540 --> 00:00:48.630
Hopefully you'll find it to be so,
Computer Hacking Forensics Investigation.

24
00:00:48.630 --> 00:00:53.458
Generically computer forensics, you hear
it often referred to as digital forensics.

25
00:00:53.458 --> 00:00:56.890
What we're gonna be spending time
on talking about working with and

26
00:00:56.890 --> 00:00:59.760
thinking through,
is the logic of how we do

27
00:00:59.760 --> 00:01:04.440
investigations on computer related crimes,
crimes that involve computers.

28
00:01:04.440 --> 00:01:08.117
Hacking incidence for instance,
people that who have used computers to

29
00:01:08.117 --> 00:01:10.658
achieve some nefarious,
and whatever it may be.

30
00:01:10.658 --> 00:01:14.462
And the methodological procedures and
techniques that help us to identify,

31
00:01:14.462 --> 00:01:18.793
gather, preserve, extract, interpret,
document and ultimately examine evidence

32
00:01:18.793 --> 00:01:22.948
from multiple perspectives is really what
computer forensics will be all about, or

33
00:01:22.948 --> 00:01:24.460
what we will focus on.

34
00:01:24.460 --> 00:01:27.020
And most importantly in ways
that are legally admissible.

35
00:01:27.020 --> 00:01:28.390
It's not just enough to say hey,

36
00:01:28.390 --> 00:01:31.930
by the way we wanna go out,
we wanna gather evidence.

37
00:01:31.930 --> 00:01:33.850
Cuz we could certainly do that.

38
00:01:33.850 --> 00:01:38.380
But if we do it in a way that is not
perceived in a court of law according

39
00:01:38.380 --> 00:01:42.390
to the rules of evidence to be legitimate,
and therefore allowable, admissible.

40
00:01:42.390 --> 00:01:43.960
It's the term that we will use.

41
00:01:43.960 --> 00:01:47.080
Then whatever we have done,
the activities will engaged in and

42
00:01:47.080 --> 00:01:50.180
the fruits of that labor will enforce
should be read or null and void.

43
00:01:50.180 --> 00:01:52.162
We will not in other words,
have access to the information.

44
00:01:52.162 --> 00:01:56.735
We'll not be able to leverage in use that
information in order to further prosecute

45
00:01:56.735 --> 00:02:00.584
or to pursue any leads that come from
that, or to pursue a case in a court

46
00:02:00.584 --> 00:02:04.833
of law, and potentially bring somebody
before the court seeking justice for

47
00:02:04.833 --> 00:02:07.040
wrongs they may have committed.

48
00:02:07.040 --> 00:02:10.920
And you see this on TV, you see this in
movies all the time, as part of a story

49
00:02:10.920 --> 00:02:15.380
line where somebody does somethings,
there is then an investigation.

50
00:02:15.380 --> 00:02:16.910
And if a rule, whatever the rule may be,

51
00:02:16.910 --> 00:02:20.420
whatever the story line is,
perhaps it's not followed correctly.

52
00:02:20.420 --> 00:02:25.630
Maybe the law enforcement, people legal
agents were acting on behalf of them.

53
00:02:25.630 --> 00:02:28.760
Whatever the case was,
did not get a search warrant, or

54
00:02:28.760 --> 00:02:31.680
did get a search warrant, but
exceeded the scope, the boundary,

55
00:02:31.680 --> 00:02:33.240
and the coverage of the search warrant.

56
00:02:33.240 --> 00:02:37.960
Or maybe because of extenuating
circumstances, they went ahead and

57
00:02:37.960 --> 00:02:39.560
engaged in certain activities.

58
00:02:39.560 --> 00:02:42.860
And then had to validate before
a judge that those activities and

59
00:02:42.860 --> 00:02:44.780
the things they did were warranted.

60
00:02:44.780 --> 00:02:48.870
Were allowed because of extenuating or
what we call exigent circumstances.

61
00:02:48.870 --> 00:02:50.140
All these variations.

62
00:02:50.140 --> 00:02:52.138
>> Adam,
I've watched plenty of gritty cop dramas.

63
00:02:52.138 --> 00:02:55.200
And I'll know,is all you have to do
is say I heard someone yell for help.

64
00:02:55.200 --> 00:02:56.135
And then you can go and
do whatever you want.

65
00:02:56.135 --> 00:02:58.227
[LAUGH]
>> Well you can do that,

66
00:02:58.227 --> 00:02:59.150
that is very true.

67
00:02:59.150 --> 00:03:02.890
But doing whatever you want,
all kidding aside, we're joking, but

68
00:03:02.890 --> 00:03:05.900
raises a really interesting
point under the thought process,

69
00:03:05.900 --> 00:03:08.760
around the thought process
as we interpret this.

70
00:03:08.760 --> 00:03:11.050
The idea is that yes,
what we just described,

71
00:03:11.050 --> 00:03:13.190
what we call exigent circumstance, right?

72
00:03:13.190 --> 00:03:17.890
Situational things that are happening
that normally we would say,

73
00:03:17.890 --> 00:03:20.020
hey you are not allowed to go
break open that door, right?

74
00:03:20.020 --> 00:03:23.135
But somebody yelling, help,
I'm being held hostage, help,

75
00:03:23.135 --> 00:03:25.740
someone's got a gun to my head,
whatever they yell.

76
00:03:25.740 --> 00:03:30.264
Or you believe as a law enforcement
officer that somebody is about

77
00:03:30.264 --> 00:03:33.060
to either have bodily harm done to them or

78
00:03:33.060 --> 00:03:37.601
something someone will be harmed
irreparably if you don't act.

79
00:03:37.601 --> 00:03:39.081
You have a little room,

80
00:03:39.081 --> 00:03:43.500
right, under the interpretation
in law to be able to take action.

81
00:03:43.500 --> 00:03:45.050
But that doesn't mean
that you can do anything.

82
00:03:45.050 --> 00:03:46.438
>> Right.
>> It means that you are allowed to do

83
00:03:46.438 --> 00:03:47.320
certain things.

84
00:03:47.320 --> 00:03:48.810
You are allowed to go in and investigate.

85
00:03:48.810 --> 00:03:51.910
You are allowed to try to
safe guard that life, right?

86
00:03:51.910 --> 00:03:54.550
We can stop somebody from
trying to shoot somebody

87
00:03:54.550 --> 00:03:57.990
by shooting them if there's
a clear threat, present danger.

88
00:03:57.990 --> 00:04:02.702
But that doesn't mean we can then go and
broadly search, and do anything we wanna

89
00:04:02.702 --> 00:04:06.738
do within that scene until we have
established certain parameters.

90
00:04:06.738 --> 00:04:09.192
Until we understand better
what has happened, and

91
00:04:09.192 --> 00:04:13.359
until depending on the circumstances, we
may have received additional permission in

92
00:04:13.359 --> 00:04:16.841
the form of writing, typically
a search warrant, from an authorized,

93
00:04:16.841 --> 00:04:20.435
in this case probably a court of law
judge, has issued a warrant that says,

94
00:04:20.435 --> 00:04:22.410
yes you're allowed to go search.

95
00:04:22.410 --> 00:04:26.570
Now if it's a crime scene we happen on
after the fact, very different, right?

96
00:04:26.570 --> 00:04:31.090
We walk in, and there are unfortunately
bodies, perhaps laying on the ground.

97
00:04:31.090 --> 00:04:34.460
Somebody's been harmed,
there's clear evidence of a crime.

98
00:04:34.460 --> 00:04:38.150
We at that point may be able to operate
differently, we're able to investigate,

99
00:04:38.150 --> 00:04:41.780
we're able to go look in the pockets of
the person that may have been harmed that

100
00:04:41.780 --> 00:04:45.630
was attacked, because now they're part of
what happened, part of the crime scene.

101
00:04:45.630 --> 00:04:49.090
So it does depend on circumstances,
as you rightly point out.

102
00:04:49.090 --> 00:04:52.790
And it depends on what we are being
asked to do in the circumstances,

103
00:04:52.790 --> 00:04:56.930
or then surround the circumstances
that we find ourselves to be involved.

104
00:04:56.930 --> 00:04:59.920
I'll have a lot more to say about
that in coming discussions.

105
00:04:59.920 --> 00:05:02.956
But the objectives of
computer forensics overall,

106
00:05:02.956 --> 00:05:05.721
thinking through the logic
of what we wanna do.

107
00:05:05.721 --> 00:05:08.400
I'm gonna actually put a list up here.

108
00:05:08.400 --> 00:05:10.690
If you just bear with me for
one second, there we go.

109
00:05:10.690 --> 00:05:13.170
If we can go full screen,
just so you can see this.

110
00:05:13.170 --> 00:05:15.210
That way we don't cut
off there on the margin.

111
00:05:15.210 --> 00:05:18.100
And a lot of this stuff we'll talk
about in these beginning episodes is

112
00:05:18.100 --> 00:05:20.180
gonna involve me throwing
up a list of things.

113
00:05:20.180 --> 00:05:23.350
Especially as we get into the rules
of evidence, and talk through them.

114
00:05:23.350 --> 00:05:24.810
Because there's just a lot of verbage,

115
00:05:24.810 --> 00:05:27.650
and a lot of detail that you
wanna make sure you're aware of.

116
00:05:27.650 --> 00:05:30.240
All of this is in the show notes,
obviously encourage

117
00:05:30.240 --> 00:05:34.870
you as we always do to take a look and
use those as a guide to help you prepare.

118
00:05:34.870 --> 00:05:37.340
Not only to apply this
knowledge in the real world,

119
00:05:37.340 --> 00:05:40.690
but those of you that may be looking
to go on and perhaps study for and

120
00:05:40.690 --> 00:05:45.220
take one or more exams in this case to see
at your final exam, you would wanna use

121
00:05:45.220 --> 00:05:49.470
this information to help you to prepare,
so objectives of computer forensic.

122
00:05:49.470 --> 00:05:53.800
Not an exhaustive list, but
certainly a major point list if you will.

123
00:05:53.800 --> 00:05:57.580
Things that are very likely to be
considered main objectives are on this

124
00:05:57.580 --> 00:05:59.310
list, and identifying, gathering, and

125
00:05:59.310 --> 00:06:02.810
preserving evidence of a cyber
crime in this case, right?

126
00:06:02.810 --> 00:06:04.180
Would be at the top of the list.

127
00:06:04.180 --> 00:06:08.340
Tracking and prosecuting perpetrators
that may have executed this crime in

128
00:06:08.340 --> 00:06:12.060
whatever court of law has jurisdiction,
wherever the crime was committed we

129
00:06:12.060 --> 00:06:16.370
would seek to then gain
access to the court there and

130
00:06:16.370 --> 00:06:20.270
prosecute a case if appropriate,
if we have evidence, if we are allowed to.

131
00:06:20.270 --> 00:06:23.410
In that jurisdiction,
we'll talk more about jurisdiction and

132
00:06:23.410 --> 00:06:27.960
the ability to be able to deal with the
specific interpretation of law by country

133
00:06:27.960 --> 00:06:29.610
in upcoming conversations as well.

134
00:06:29.610 --> 00:06:32.570
But remember, law generically

135
00:06:32.570 --> 00:06:36.030
is the same everywhere we go in
the sense that almost without exception,

136
00:06:36.030 --> 00:06:42.090
every country will have a set of laws that
addresses things like what is a crime?

137
00:06:42.090 --> 00:06:43.330
How was it committed?

138
00:06:43.330 --> 00:06:47.150
Under what circumstances do we or don't
we have the right to seek redress and

139
00:06:47.150 --> 00:06:50.800
to prosecute a court or
rather prosecute a crime that occurred?

140
00:06:50.800 --> 00:06:53.590
But every country will interpret
their laws differently,

141
00:06:53.590 --> 00:06:57.140
will apply them differently, and
will draft them differently.

142
00:06:57.140 --> 00:07:00.180
And as a broad statement, not every
country will be different because many

143
00:07:00.180 --> 00:07:02.650
countries come from the perspective or

144
00:07:02.650 --> 00:07:06.430
share the perspective of a common
foundation for their legal systems,

145
00:07:06.430 --> 00:07:10.890
whether it's common law under the English
system or whatever the case may be.

146
00:07:10.890 --> 00:07:12.950
And as a result,
there's a lot of similarity there.

147
00:07:12.950 --> 00:07:16.290
But there are unique differences and
subtle differences that we need to be

148
00:07:16.290 --> 00:07:22.410
aware of as forensics experts,
as investigators, as representatives of

149
00:07:22.410 --> 00:07:26.880
a process that allows us to gather
information and allows us to do so

150
00:07:26.880 --> 00:07:31.550
on a forensically sound and appropriate
way following the rules of evidence.

151
00:07:31.550 --> 00:07:33.990
Whatever they may be
based on the locality and

152
00:07:33.990 --> 00:07:35.970
the legal jurisdictions enforced there.

153
00:07:35.970 --> 00:07:39.470
And following and establishing
a chain of custody of evidence for

154
00:07:39.470 --> 00:07:42.580
an important term that we'll come
back to time and again here.

155
00:07:42.580 --> 00:07:45.820
We have to follow the rules in other
words and play the game correctly.

156
00:07:45.820 --> 00:07:48.468
To then seek the end game that
we're looking for, and hopefully,

157
00:07:48.468 --> 00:07:49.520
if everything goes well.

158
00:07:49.520 --> 00:07:53.879
And we can prove beyond a reasonable doubt
that somebody legitimately seems to have

159
00:07:53.879 --> 00:07:55.510
engaged in these activities.

160
00:07:55.510 --> 00:08:00.300
Bring them before the court and
allow a jury or a judge depending on the.

161
00:08:00.300 --> 00:08:03.990
Court that we are in and the kind of legal
system we are involved with to render

162
00:08:03.990 --> 00:08:06.730
a ruling as to whether they
are innocent or guilty.

163
00:08:06.730 --> 00:08:08.990
And if innocent,
allow them to go on their way.

164
00:08:08.990 --> 00:08:12.910
If guilty, allow for some sort of
punishment, whatever may be allowed and

165
00:08:12.910 --> 00:08:16.650
applicable under the law to be assigned,
whether it's a criminal case or

166
00:08:16.650 --> 00:08:17.860
a civil case.

167
00:08:17.860 --> 00:08:20.330
Again, depending on the kind of law and
legal system we're in

168
00:08:20.330 --> 00:08:24.620
criminal case would involve traditionally
jail time, if found guilty.

169
00:08:24.620 --> 00:08:28.910
Whereas a civil case would traditionally
involve some sort of financial penalty,

170
00:08:28.910 --> 00:08:29.865
if you are found guilty.

171
00:08:29.865 --> 00:08:32.570
And there may be some other
things that go on with that, but

172
00:08:32.570 --> 00:08:36.835
those are the main thought processes
around criminal versus civil cases.

173
00:08:36.835 --> 00:08:39.745
So we have to think about
these things as we think about

174
00:08:39.745 --> 00:08:41.785
the objectives of computer forensics.

175
00:08:41.785 --> 00:08:45.117
We also have to look at the fact
that we may interpret document and

176
00:08:45.117 --> 00:08:47.830
present evidence and
have to do so, as I mentioned,

177
00:08:47.830 --> 00:08:51.432
in an admissible way that would allow for
prosecution to take place.

178
00:08:51.432 --> 00:08:55.986
Again, if appropriate, if the evidence

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne take a few moments to explain input text and special characters in Word 2016. Here they talk about adding basic text like letters, numbers, and symbols like \*/%/@. They also explain the difference between backspace and delete, paragraphs and line-breaks, and tabs. Finally, they explain the Show/Hide button's function and even give you some history about where the different character sets come from.
